\begin{soln}
  For the sake of contradiction, assume such a
  function exists. Note that as $f(x)$ is differentiable,
  $f(f(x))$ is also differentiable and so is $f'(x)=f(f(x))$.

  Note that $f'(x) = f(f(x)) > 0$ implies
  $f$ is strictly increasing.
  This along with $f > 0$ implies that
  $\lim_{x \to -\oo} f(x)$ exists.
  (Details are left to the reader.)

  Let $\ell = \lim_{x \to -\oo} f(x)$. By LMVT, there exists
  $c_x \in (x, x+1)$ such that
  \[
    f'(c_x) = \frac{f(x+1) - f(x)}{(x+1) - x} = f(x+1) - f(x)
    \qquad \forall\, x \in \RR
  .\]
  Then note $\lim_{x \to -\oo} c_x = -\oo$. So,
  \[
    \lim_{x \to -\oo} f'(c_x) = \ell - \ell = 0
  .\]

  Differentiating our original equation, we get
  \[
    f''(x) = f'(f(x)) \cdot f'(x) > 0
  .\]
  Therefore $f'(x)$ is also strictly increasing. Recall that
  we derived $f'(x)> 0$
  for all $x\in \RR$. So, by an analogous logic,
  $\lim_{x \to -\oo} f'(x)$ also exists. Thus
  \[
    \lim_{x \to -\oo} f'(x) = \lim_{x \to -\oo} f'(c_x) = 0
  .\]
  Plugging this back into our original equation, we get
  \[
    0 = \lim_{x \to -\oo} f'(x) = \lim_{x \to -\oo} f(f(x))
    = f(\lim_{x \to -\oo} f(x)) = f(\ell)
  \] 
  which contradicts the fact that $f(x) > 0$ for all
  $x \in \RR$.

  Thus our initial claim must have been false and we are done.
\end{soln}
